title: Amores VI
text:
i like
to think that on
the flower you gave me when we
loved

     the far-
departed mouth sweetly-saluted
lingers.
        if one marvel

seeing the hunger of my
lips for a dead thing,
i shall instruct
him silently with becoming

steps to seek
your face    and i
entreat,by certain foolish perfect
hours

     dead too,
if that he come receive
him as your lover sumptuously
being

kind
     because i trust him to
your grace,and for
in his own land

he is called death.
seo_description: A poem by E. E. Cummings in “Tulips and Chimneys”
